commit.message:
CI: Add a temprorary fix for truffleruby-24.0.0

See https://github.com/oracle/truffleruby/issues/3478#issuecomment-2015315471

Remove deprecated use of fptr->fd

Direct access is disallowed since ruby-3.4.
Add renewed certificate for x509 signature of gem releases
Bump VERSION to 1.5.6
Add release notes for pg-1.5.6

Merge pull request #559 from larskanis/reset-with-dns

Renew address resolution in conn.reset

verification.payload:
tree cab236c308fae7ccce461837268182e6b06f8aa8
parent 21ca5ccdf966c4e54c742d272156e8d0b15b4968
parent 016c17c9c9bbc51bf5fab2087ad485367c789118
author Lars Kanis <lars@greiz-reinsdorf.de> 1709315564 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1709315564 +0100

Merge pull request #559 from larskanis/reset-with-dns

Renew address resolution in conn.reset

commit.message:
libpq resolves the host address while PQreset, but ruby-pg doesn't. This is because we explicit set the `hostaddr` connection parameter when the connection is established the first time. This prevents a newly DNS resolution when running PQresetStart.

This patch adds DNS resolution to `conn.reset`
Since we can not change the connection parameters after connection start, the underlying PGconn pointer is exchanged in reset_start2. This is done by a PQfinish() + PQconnectStart() sequence. That way the `hostaddr` parameter is updated and a new connection is established with it.

There is a `/etc/hosts` and `sudo` based test in the specs.
The behavior of libpq is slightly different to that of ruby-pg.
It can be verified by the following code:

```ruby
require "pg"

puts "pg version: #{PG::VERSION}"

system "sudo sed -i 's/.* abcd/::1 abcd/g' /etc/hosts"
conn = PG.connect host: "abcd", password: "l"
conn.exec("select 1")
p conn.conninfo_hash.slice(:host, :hostaddr, :port)

system "sudo sed -i 's/.* abcd/127.0.0.1 abcd/g' /etc/hosts"
conn.reset
conn.exec("select 1")
p conn.conninfo_hash.slice(:host, :hostaddr, :port)

system "sudo sed -i 's/.* abcd/::2 abcd/g' /etc/hosts"
conn.reset
conn.exec("select 1")
p conn.conninfo_hash.slice(:host, :hostaddr, :port)
```

This gives the following output showing, that the IP address is updated:
```
pg version: 1.5.5
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>"::1", :port=>"5432"}
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>"127.0.0.1", :port=>"5432"}
ruby-pg/lib/pg/connection.rb:573:in `reset_start2': connection to server at "::2", port 5432 failed: Network is unreachable (PG::ConnectionBad)
	Is the server running on that host and accepting TCP/IP connections?
```

Whereas libpq resolves similarly with `async_api=false`, but doesn't raise the error in `conn.reset` but in the subsequent `conn.exec`.

```
pg version: 1.5.5
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>nil, :port=>"5432"}
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>nil, :port=>"5432"}
test-reset-dns.rb:18:in `sync_exec': no connection to the server (PG::UnableToSend)
```

Fixes #558

libpq resolves the host address while PQreset, but ruby-pg doesn't. This is because we explicit set the `hostaddr` connection parameter when the connection is established the first time. This prevents a newly DNS resolution when running PQresetStart.

This patch adds DNS resolution to `conn.reset`
Since we can not change the connection parameters after connection start, the underlying PGconn pointer is exchanged in reset_start2. This is done by a PQfinish() + PQconnectStart() sequence. That way the `hostaddr` parameter is updated and a new connection is established with it.

There is a `/etc/hosts` and `sudo` based test in the specs.
The behavior of libpq is slightly different to that of ruby-pg.
It can be verified by the following code:

```ruby
require "pg"

puts "pg version: #{PG::VERSION}"

system "sudo sed -i 's/.* abcd/::1 abcd/g' /etc/hosts"
conn = PG.connect host: "abcd", password: "l"
conn.exec("select 1")
p conn.conninfo_hash.slice(:host, :hostaddr, :port)

system "sudo sed -i 's/.* abcd/127.0.0.1 abcd/g' /etc/hosts"
conn.reset
conn.exec("select 1")
p conn.conninfo_hash.slice(:host, :hostaddr, :port)

system "sudo sed -i 's/.* abcd/::2 abcd/g' /etc/hosts"
conn.reset
conn.exec("select 1")
p conn.conninfo_hash.slice(:host, :hostaddr, :port)
```

This gives the following output showing, that the IP address is updated:
```
pg version: 1.5.5
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>"::1", :port=>"5432"}
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>"127.0.0.1", :port=>"5432"}
ruby-pg/lib/pg/connection.rb:573:in `reset_start2': connection to server at "::2", port 5432 failed: Network is unreachable (PG::ConnectionBad)
	Is the server running on that host and accepting TCP/IP connections?
```

Whereas libpq resolves similarly with `async_api=false`, but doesn't raise the error in `conn.reset` but in the subsequent `conn.exec`.

```
pg version: 1.5.5
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>nil, :port=>"5432"}
{:host=>"abcd", :hostaddr=>nil, :port=>"5432"}
test-reset-dns.rb:18:in `sync_exec': no connection to the server (PG::UnableToSend)
```

Fixes #558

commit.message:
Make bigdecimal an optional dependency

It's a gem in ruby-3.4+, so that users shouldn't be forced to use it.

Don't ship POT files in gem.

README.md is already translated when it reaches the gem form,
no need to ship the files for translation.

Merge pull request #548 from larskanis/fix-x86

Fix BinaryEncoder::Timestamp and possible buffer overflows on 32 bit platforms

commit.message:
Fix possible buffer overflows on 32 bit systems

Comparing pointers after adding lengths is dangerous, since the length can overflow the pointer, so that the comparison leads to wrong results.
Comparing lengths only fixes this issue.

This lead to segfault in the following spec on x86:

	it "should raise an error at grabage COPY format" do
		expect{ decoder.decode("123\t \0\\\t\\") }
			.to raise_error(ArgumentError, /premature.*at position: 7$/)
	end

Merge pull request #547 from jackorp/fix_timestamp_conversion_for_x86

Explicitly retype timespec fields to int64_t to fix compatibility with 32bit arches.

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1697821546 +0200

Merge pull request #547 from jackorp/fix_timestamp_conversion_for_x86

Explicitly retype timespec fields to int64_t to fix compatibility with 32bit arches.

commit.message:
Explicitly retype timespec fields to int64_t to fix compatibility with 32bit arches.

Timespec fields' time_t type is not guaranteed to be any particular integer.
Tests with binary timestamp conversion are failing on 32bit arches (e.g. intel x86)
until they are retyped into int64_t, which fixes the issue with encoding the Time instances.

Decoder doesn't need adjusting. It returns the correct time from the encoded binary representation.

Resolves: https://github.com/ged/ruby-pg/issues/545
CI: shorter job names for better readablility on github.com
CI: Uate to PostgreSQL-16
Enable english error messages in tests, as some specs depend on them

Update windows binary build to PostgreSQL-16

We never built with ICU support, but that flag has to be disabled explicit in PG-16.
Update error codes to PostgreSQL-16
Add new x509 cert, used for pg-1.5.4
